awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Functional Proceduralization of 3D Geometric Models
awd_abstract_narration:
While computational power and digital storage availability have increased tremendously in recent decades, the creation of useful 3D digital content is still difficult.  Although we can find huge collections of existing 3D models on the Internet, these models are typically geometrically disorganized which severely limits their utility.  The vision underlying this research is to facilitate semi-automatic, controllable content creation and editing of large and complex 3D models for use in digital simulation, visualization, entertainment, education, and cultural heritage, by converting unstructured data into organized and easily editable representations.  With that goal in mind, this project will create digital tools that proceduralize a geometric model provided as input into a set of meaningful rules and their parameters so that the model is compact, can be altered in an intuitive way, and is fast to render.  Project outcomes are expected to have broad impact in computer graphics applications spanning a wide variety of domains.

The methodology underlying this work is to find a procedural representation (i.e., algorithm, rule set, and parameter values) that can generate a given input model while considering its function.  A key novelty of the approach is the automatic production of a procedural representation and the learning of the function as well as the semantic structure of the object.  The project will explore generation both of procedural representations in programming languages such as Python and Java Script and by using novel procedural representations such as adaptive geometric graph grammars or extensions to shape and split grammars.  As a result, the methodology will help content creation by enabling the generation of functionally-valid variants of the same object, exposing parameters for performing high-level or low-level alterations, and completing the object with plausible details.  The work will proceed with three main components: atomization (discovery of the atomic, or terminal, elements of the input model); patternization (finding and enumerating the parameterized rules and/or the parameter values that are collectively used to produce the input object); and synthetization (providing algorithms and tools to enable the efficient and intuitive generation of synthetic variations of the input object or objects).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our project facilitates semi-automatic and controllable content creation and edition of large and complex 3D models for use in digital simulation, visualization, entertainment, education, and cultural heritage by converting unstructured data into organized and easily editable procedural representations. We provide digital tools that proceduralize an input model into a set of meaningful rules and their parameters so that the model can easily be altered in an intuitive way that is compact and fast to render. We sought to find a procedural representation in a form of rules or even code in a programming language. Our methodology is to find a procedural representation (e.g., algorithm, rule set, and parameter values) that can generate a provided input model while considering the function of the underlying model.

 

A key novelty of our approach is the automatic production of a procedural representation and the learning of the function as well as the semantic structure of the object. We have explored various procedural representations, such as programming languages, graphs, and encapsulations in deep neural networks. As a result, our methodology helps content creation by enabling the generation of functionally-valid variants of the same object, exposing parameters for performing high-level or low-level alterations, and completing the object with plausible details. In particular, our approach has been applied to a variety of data types and has been used in a range of applications ranging from world-scale urban planning, crowd and evacuation planning, and vegetation and tree modeling.

 

With regards to urban planning, we have enabled and deployed tools to automatically create a procedural model of buildings worldwide starting with as little as a single photograph or of large cities from a single satellite image. Our results indicate we can obtain similar or better quality than competing significantly more heavy weight acquisition efforts. Further, we enable novel tools for extreme urban weather mitigation, what-if scenario urban planning, and more.

 

We also model urban vegetation with a particular focus on trees. Our proceduralization technique has enabled to localize and count individual trees automatically from globally-available satellite imagery. Also, we have been able to infer tree positioning rules in urban areas and codify them into rules. In addition, we proposed to metrics to evaluate the visual plausibility of our procedural models.

 

Our methodology has also been applied to crowd modeling. Our proceduralization method has enabled using real-data to help model and understand how crowds can be influenced at a large scale by signs and forms of communication information to them. In addition, we discovered what tools sets are most useful to design crowd simulations.

 

Finally, our work has been disseminated via publications, conference presentations, news articles, a TEDx talk, and has resulted in several graduated PhD students that have and are applying the techniques of this project to commercial applications. In addition, the PI team has capitalized on the success of this project to successfully apply the knowledge gained in this project to subsequent funded projects and additional papers and presentations.
